Article.Abstract: A predominant T-cell epitope of Escherichia coli outer membrane protein F (OmpF) that encompasses amino acids 295 to 314 was identified in H-2(d) mice. BALB/c-derived T-cell hybridomas generated against this region were CD3(+), CD4(+), CD8(-), and T-cell receptor alphabeta(+) and secreted TH-1-associated cytokines (interleukin-2 [IL-2] and gamma interferon), but not a TH-2-associated cytokine (IL-4), when restimulated with peptide 295-314. Class II(+) mouse lymphoma (A20) cells, but not class II(-) mouse mastocytoma (P815) cells, supported IL-2 secretion of hybridomas when substituted for syngeneic splenocytes as antigen-presenting cells (APCs). Antibodies specific for I-E(d) blocked IL-2 secretion by hybridomas, but I-A(d)-specific antiserum did not. When transfected L cells expressing I-A(d) (AalphaAbeta(d)), I-E(d) (EalphaEbeta(d)), or the hybrid molecule I-EalphaAbeta(d) were used as APCs, hybridomas recognized peptide only when presented by the I-E(d)-transfected cells. When peptide 295-314 truncated at either the C or the N terminus of the sequence was used, the minimal epitope was determined. Critical residues were determined by using alanine-substituted peptide analogues. T-cell hybridomas were only stimulated by peptides that encompassed amino acids 295 to 303 (9-mer), and the core sequence required a minimum of three additional amino acids at either the amino or the carboxy terminus to induce IL-2 secretion. Critical residues were determined to be phenylalanine at position 295, threonine at position 300, and tyrosines at positions 301 and 302. This study is the first to identify a minimal T-cell epitope and major histocompatibility complex restriction element of the OmpF protein and confirms previous observations that there is considerable degeneracy in the length of peptides that can bind I-E(d) and variability in the amino acid composition of the C and N termini of these peptides.
Article.ArticleTitle: Identification of an I-Ed-restricted T-cell epitope of Escherichia coli outer membrane protein F.
Article.Affiliations: Center for Food Safety and Applied Nutrition, Immunobiology Branch, Food and Drug Administration, 8301 Muirkirk Road, Laurel, MD 20708, USA. kwillia2@cfsan.fda.gov.
Article.ArticleChemicalList: Amino Acids;Epitopes;Histocompatibility Antigens Class II;I-E-antigen;OmpF protein;Porins
Article.ArticleMeshHeadingsList: Amino Acids(metabolism); Animals; Epitopes(immunology); Escherichia coli(immunology); Histocompatibility Antigens Class II(immunology); Hybridomas(immunology); Major Histocompatibility Complex(immunology); Mice; Porins(immunology; metabolism); T-Lymphocytes(immunology)

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: BALB/c mice immunized with native porin (OmpF) emulsified in colonization factor antigen were used to develop T-cell hybridomas specific for immunodominant determinant OmpF amino acids 295-314.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: The epitope-specific hybridomas reacted with the peptide fragment containing the epitope.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: BALB/c mice immunized with native porin (OmpF) emulsified in colonization factor antigen were used to develop T-cell hybridomas specific for immunodominant determinant OmpF amino acids 295-314.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: This optimal epitope was identified by peptide truncation studies. Alanine-substituted analogs of the epitope showed that residues F1, V3, T6, Y7, and Y8 were critical for T cells activation.
